009package imagingbook.common.geometry.ellipse.project;
010
011import static imagingbook.common.math.Arithmetic.sqr;
012import static java.lang.Math.abs;
013import static java.lang.Math.max;
014import static java.lang.Math.pow;
015
016import imagingbook.common.geometry.ellipse.GeometricEllipse;
017
018/**
019 * <p>
020 * Calculates the closest point on the ellipse for a given 2D point inside or
021 * outside the ellipse, using orthogonal projection of points onto the ellipse.
022 * This is a robust algorithm based on [1]. See Sec.11.2.2 (Alg. 11.9) of [2]
023 * for details. This version uses the Newton-method for root finding, which is
024 * quick but may fail to return a valid result if the target point is close to
025 * the x- or y-axis. See {@link OrthogonalEllipseProjector} for a robust
026 * solution or {@link ConfocalConicEllipseProjector} for an approximate but
027 * non-iterative (i.e., fast) alternative.
028 * </p>
029 * <p>
030 * [1] D. Eberly: "Distance from a point to an ellipse, an ellipsoid, or a
031 * hyperellipsoid", Technical Report, Geometric Tools, www.geometrictools.com,
032 * Redmont, WA (June 2013). <br>
033 * [2] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; An
034 * Algorithmic Introduction</em>, 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
035 * </p>
036 * 
037 * @author WB
038 * @version 2022/04/09
039 * @see OrthogonalEllipseProjector
040 * @see ConfocalConicEllipseProjector
041 */
042public class OrthogonalEllipseProjectorNewton extends EllipseProjector {
043        
044        private final static double NewtonMinStep = 1e-6;
045        private final static int MaxIterations = 100;
046        
047        private final double ra, rb, ra2, rb2;
048        private int lastIterationCount = 0;     // number of root-finding iterations performed in last projection
049        
050        public OrthogonalEllipseProjectorNewton(GeometricEllipse ellipse) {
051                super(ellipse);
052                this.ra = ellipse.ra;
053                this.rb = ellipse.rb;
054                this.ra2 = sqr(ra);
055                this.rb2 = sqr(rb);
056        }
057        
058        @Override
059        protected double[] projectCanonical(double[] u1) {
060                // coordinates of p (mapped to first quadrant)
061                final double u = u1[0]; 
062                final double v = u1[1]; 
063                
064                double[] ub = null;     // the unknown ellipse point
065
066                if (u + v < 1e-6) {     // (u,v) is very close to the ellipse center; u,v >= 0
067                        ub = new double[] {0, rb};
068                }
069                else {                                          
070                        double t = max(ra * u - ra2, rb * v - rb2);
071                        double gprev = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
072                        double deltaT, deltaG;
073                        int k = 0;
074                        do {
075                                k = k + 1;
076                                double g  = sqr((ra * u) / (t + ra2)) + sqr((rb * v) / (t + rb2)) - 1;
077                                double dg = 2 * (sqr(ra * u) / pow(t + ra2, 3) + sqr(rb * v) / pow(t + rb2, 3));
078                                deltaT = g / dg;
079                                t = t + deltaT;                         // Newton iteration
080                                
081                                // in rare cases g(t) is very flat and checking deltaT is not enough for convergence!
082                                deltaG = g - gprev;                     // change of g value
083                                gprev = g;      
084                                
085                        }  while(abs(deltaT) > NewtonMinStep && abs(deltaG) > NewtonMinStep && k < MaxIterations);
086                        
087                        lastIterationCount = k;         // remember iteration count
088                        
089                        if (k >= MaxIterations) {
090                                throw new RuntimeException("max. mumber of iterations exceeded");
091                        }
092                        
093                        ub = new double[] {ra2 * u / (t + ra2), rb2 * v / (t + rb2)};
094                }
095                return ub;
096        }
097
098        // for statistics only
099        
100        public int getLastIterationCount() {
101                return this.lastIterationCount;
102        }
103
104}
